title: Omelette Basics

items.name: Eggs per omelette
items.details: 2 eggs is the standard baseline. Use 3 eggs for a larger, fluffier, more filling omelette. Use 1 egg only if adding a lot of fillings or doing a thin French-style one.

items.name: Butter goes in the pan, not the eggs
items.details: Do not mix butter into the egg base. Beat eggs with salt (and optionally a splash of water or milk for softer eggs). Heat the pan, add butter, and pour in the eggs when the butter melts and stops foaming.

items.name: Why not butter in the eggs
items.details: Butter mixed into the eggs makes the texture greasy. Butter in the pan controls heat and prevents sticking, giving better curds and cleaner flavor.

items.name: For richer eggs
items.details: Add cream or milk to the egg mixture, not butter.

notes: If cooking the omelette as a standalone meal, go with 3 eggs. If pairing with toast, potatoes, or veggies, 2 eggs is the right portion.
